history.content:
EE 120/ ME 132 content shows up pretty marginally in 106a, but is a sizeable part of 106b. I haven't taken 132 (so take my advice with a grain of salt!), but I did take 120 concurrently with 106a and I definitely could have taken the class without it and not have been impacted by more than half an hour extra learning some content. Taking ME 134/EE 128 concurrently with or before 106b will be enough for that class as well.

But outside of just these two classes and for knowledge as a whole, 120 is a pretty fun, relatively light workload class that probably won't teach you anything new controls wise, but might give you more theoretical rigour and will be useful if you plan on doing signal processing related things, like taking EE 123. If you felt unsatisfied with some definitions or formula for laplace transforms, then 120 might help with that too. But, having taken 132, you also have the background needed to self study all the relevant content as well. If you want to go down this route, http://inst.eecs.berkeley.edu/~ee120/fa19/ is an excellent page.

Should I worry about taking EE 120 if I've already taken ME 132 and did reasonably well in the class? I'm planning on taking EECS C106a in the fall and may take EECS C106b in the spring, if that impacts anything.
history.subject: EE 120 vs ME 132
